case_vignette: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a recurrent pruritic rash on his face and scalp. He reports that he has been using a new shaving cream once a week for the past 5 months. A year ago, he was diagnosed with HIV and is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He drinks several six-packs of beer weekly. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the rash is shown. A similar rash is seen near the hairline of the scalp and greasy yellow scales are seen at the margins of the eyelids.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

I've been having this itchy rash on my face and scalp that keeps coming back for the past three months.

Thank you for providing more information. Based on what you've told me, it's possible that you may have a condition called seborrheic dermatitis. This is a common skin condition that can cause redness, itching, and flaking of the skin, particularly on the scalp, face, and other areas with a lot of oil glands. The greasy yellow scales you mentioned are a common symptom of seborrheic dermatitis. Can you tell me if you've noticed any other symptoms or if you have a history of allergies or skin conditions?
I haven't noticed any other symptoms and I don't have a history of allergies or skin conditions.

Great, that helps to narrow it down. Based on what you've told me, it's likely that you have seborrheic dermatitis. This condition is caused by an overgrowth of a type of yeast called Malassezia, which can irritate the skin and cause inflammation. It can also be triggered by hormonal changes, stress, and poor hygiene.

To treat seborrheic dermatitis, I would recommend using an antifungal cream or ointment that contains ingredients such as ketoconazole or selenium sulfide. These medications can help to control the growth of the yeast and reduce the inflammation. You can apply the cream or ointment to the affected area twice a day, morning and night, for several weeks until the symptoms improve.
